text: So now I guess an important ingredient we've seen for defining a generative model is the ability to use the same variable in multiple places.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So that's formalized in terms of these co-monoids.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So you have an operation that splits a wire and it's co-commutative.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So if you split and then you swap, it's the same thing as just splitting.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: It's got a unit which is discarding, so if you split and then if you copy something and then you discard, or if you split and then you terminate the wire, you haven't done anything.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And it's co-associative, so it doesn't matter if you copy the left-hand copy or the right-hand copy, you get three identical copies.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And yeah, I guess the main two axioms for being a Cartesian category are these two.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So the second one, I guess you can call normalization.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So essentially in terms of stochastic maps, what this means is that if you apply a stochastic map and then take the weight of the results, take the mass of the results for any distribution coming in here,
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: it's the same as the mass of the input.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So essentially, it takes a normalized distribution to a normalized distribution.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And so on the left-hand side, it's more controversial.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: It's not going to be true in the category of stochastic maps.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: This says that f is deterministic.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So if you perform f and then copy the result, it's the same as copying the inputs and performing f twice.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And I guess if you take the special case where F has no input, this means that essentially F can be copied, means that it's deterministic in a sense that performing F, if F was a toss coin, you would take F through a coin and then copy the results.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: You would get a different result as if you toss two coins, right?
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: The second one is going to hold in terms of Bayesian probability theory if you have normalized processes.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And it's this idea of essentially you can also formalize it as causality.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So if you discard the output, it cannot influence the input.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And yeah, the first one is essentially what brings you back to the world of deterministic processes.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So it's a good way of characterizing which stochastic map is in fact a deterministic one.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And so if you have these two axioms, you're called the Cartesian category.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: If you don't have them, you're called the copy-discard category.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And so I guess in our context, we are really interested in copy-discard categories where these two are different processes.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And yeah, I guess what can you prove at this abstract level of generality is a really nice no-cloning theorem where you don't need to assume any complex numbers or any quantum stuff.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And in fact, it holds as well in the context of probability theory.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: and I think it's called the no broadcasting theorem in that case.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: But the idea is that you cannot have both cups and cats and copying.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So here, I guess you assume that you have cups,
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And then because you have copying, then the copy of a cup is also going to be two cups, right?
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: But you can also do some shenanigans where you bend the wires because copying is co-commutative.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So on one side, you're going to swap the wires.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And now you've essentially proved that two cups like this side by side are actually equal to two cups nested inside out.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: you bend all the legs and you get that a swap is equal to the identity, which is basically, yeah, it means you've done something wrong, right?
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Like if you can't even distinguish swapping stuff from not doing anything, your category is very much trivial.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So I guess that's the main, the no cloning theorem is that if you're both compact, so you have cups and caps and copying, now you have to be a trivial category in the sense that everything is a,
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: essentially a scalar multiple of the identity.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So that's not the case in probability theory.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So probability theory also has this no-cloning feature, and that's essentially, well, you can't copy something if it's a non-trivial distribution.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: You can't copy a correlated state, right?
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: The same way you can't copy an entangled state in quantum.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: um so yeah um i guess um the last ingredient we need in order to talk about active inference is the idea of normalization um and a in the context of string diagrams that's going to be represented as i was saying it by hierarchical diagrams where you have a sub diagram that's uh inducted lines will just represent the normalization of it with some caveat if there's no support for the um
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: for the particular state.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So here you have a stochastic map from X to Y and you put it inside of a dotted line and you get its normalization.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So I guess to get inside is not really a stochastic map anymore.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: It's more of a
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: just any measurable function, not necessarily normalized, and the thing outside becomes a proper stochastic map.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And that means for any measurable function, you can decompose it in terms of something that's normalized and then something that you discount.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So these three lines are the discounting operation that we drew as a white dot before.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So essentially, here, that equation tells you that every measurable function is going to be a normalized one up to some renormalization.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So I guess it's sort of intuitive.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And also, normalization behaves nicely with respect to parallel composition.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So if you have f and g, and then parallel, you normalize them, you get the normalization of f times the normalization of g.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: It behaves well with respect to copying a particular variable of your generative model.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: But the thing it doesn't behave well with is the composition.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So it's not true that the normalization of composition is the composition of normalization.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And that's essentially what gives you the difference between a Jeffrey update and a Perl update in the context of Bayesian inference.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So on the left hand side, you've got a Jeffrey update where you first normalize and then pre-compose with the prior.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: On the right-hand side, you've got your Perl update, where you do first the precomposition with the prior, and then you normalize.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And so I guess here on the left, if you want to obtain something normalized overall, you will need to renormalize.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So you get two normalizations.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: On the right-hand side, you only get one.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And that's the difference.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: That's the fact that normalization is not a functor.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: In a sense, it doesn't commute with the composition.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So then another kind of bubble we'll need is taking the logarithm of a function.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So if we have a function from x to the reals, positive reals, we can take its logarithm.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: This function is just going to be, if we think of the category of measurable functions, well, the empty diagram is going to correspond to the real numbers, to the one-dimensional space.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And so such a function will just be a box, an effect, which takes something and gives you just a renormalization factor, right?
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And now if you have such an effect, you can put it into a green box and you'll get the
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: the negative log of it.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So that's sort of a mere sort of notational gadget.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And essentially, yeah, it only becomes interesting if you start using it inside a more complex diagram where this green box will not commute past the composition and will give some interesting hierarchical structure to your diagram.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And I guess here I'm just copying some caveats from the Tor et al paper.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And yeah, I guess they give some pointers to some interesting category theory that could be formalized to explore these log boxes further.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: But in our context, what we need them to is essentially, yeah, we just want the nice properties of logarithms.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: If this copying operator acts like essentially a product, then we want that the log of a product is the sum of the logs, so you get this nice operation, nice homomorphism property of the log.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: The discarding operator acts like the unit of this multiplication.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So the log of the units will be zero.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And then you get this nice product rule, this sort of Leibniz rule for the logarithm of
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: of a tensor product in that sense will be the sum of two tensor products.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So that's also the kind of equation you'll find in an automatic differentiation framework where the gradient of D tensor E is going to be the gradient of D plus the gradient of E. And finally, if X is deterministic, so that's what they call sharp states, then it also commutes past the log.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So you get this nice property of the logarithm, which allows to take a diagram with these green boxes and sort of massage them into a sum of diagrams.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And finally, you can define this notion of open vibrational free energy.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

speaker: SPEAKER_01

speaker: SPEAKER_01

speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: the free energy of the tensor will be some composition of the individual thing.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So I guess in the case of tensor is the simplest case.

speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: But I guess that's sort of the main theorem of that
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: categorical active inference framework is that you get this idea that the free energy for the whole is composition of the free energy of its parts.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And essentially, monoidal category theory gives you the high-level layer of abstraction to describe these sorts of compositional phenomena.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And yeah, I guess with this sort of foundational theory, you want to turn it into application.

speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: of active inference implementation in terms of diagrams.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Well, we have most of the finite dimensional case implemented already in the sense that if your random variable span is a categorical distribution, then you can turn this Bayesian inference problem into a tensor network contraction problem.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: We have a bunch of automatic and diagrammatic differentiation algorithms implemented with some compilation with the JAX library.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So essentially, you can take your diagram and compile it into a bunch of GPU code for very fast execution.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And finally, the sort of more experimental, more speculative part of the library is this idea of the geometry of interaction, where you formalize bidirectional processes.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: But there's this very interesting idea of a Bayesian lens where you have these bidirectional operations that also have some stochastic side to them.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So essentially, you can talk about updates, about the forward part of your process being some inference and the backward part being some update.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And this geometry of interaction will give you a way of composing these updates together.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: in a compositional structure of Bayesian inference.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So we already have the sort of purely abstract implementation of this geometry of interaction.

speaker: SPEAKER_01

speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: If you take finite dimensional as a first step and you look at how it updates, you should be able to implement it in a purely compositional way with DiscoPy and also be able to draw the results in the end.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And I guess what's missing would be a more continuous implementation where I guess to go beyond finite dimensional, you need some sort of more involved implementation based on monads, I guess is a very well-developed theory on the category side.
